title: Distributed Estimation and Gap-Free Analysis of Canonical Correlations
abstract:
Massive data analysis calls for distributed algorithms and theories. We
design a multi-round distributed algorithm for canonical correlation analysis.
We construct principal directions through the convex formulation of canonical
correlation analysis and use the shift-and-invert preconditioning iteration to
expedite the convergence rate. This distributed algorithm is
communication-efficient. The resultant estimate achieves the same convergence
rate as if all observations were pooled together, but does not impose stringent
restrictions on the number of machines. We take a gap-free analysis to bypass
the widely used yet unrealistic assumption of an explicit gap between the
successive canonical correlations in the canonical correlation analysis.
Extensive simulations and applications to three benchmark image data are
conducted to demonstrate the empirical performance of our proposed algorithms
and theories.
